**Original Post:**
Curious what others thinkâ€¦I believe that timed billing codes is one of the worst things for our profession, and we are basically the only profession that has them.  It diminishes our value, and dictates how we treat if we want to make any money.  If I have a post op shoulder patient, I can do very effective joint mobilization and PROM in 15 minutes, but why should I get paid less for that visit, than if I make someone do a bunch of exercises with some supervision.  Times codes are forcing PTs to do fillers to waste time so that they can get decent reimbursement, even if it isnâ€™t necessary, or even if it isnâ€™t in patients best interest.  I think this is the number one thing the APTA should focus on, if anyone here is active in it.  Very curious what others think please!  Thanks, Iâ€™ll get off my soap box nowâ€¦

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Sounds like you are a business owner. Assuming you are, you are in the best position to create what you want. 
...
Reading through the comments and your responses it sounds like 1.) you want to earn more money, 2.) you want to deliver a better patient care experience, and 3.) you want to do it at a price point that you would pay if you were the patient. 
...
Does that sound about right?
...
Rather than focusing on someone else changing a system that won't likely change in our lifetime, why not put that energy into something you can control more easily. 
...
Create the business that solves the problems you want to solve. 
...
Look at business models outside of healthcare that are already achieving these goals. 
...
Starbucks is a bank that sells overpriced coffee. A standard coffee shop can't compete because they are trying to operate in a failing business model. 
...
Facebook and Google make hundreds of billions on selling what people give them for free.
...
Barnes and Nobel survived and is opening 30 new stores despite Amazon's attack on book sales because of their are a real estate holdings business. 
...
I can run a profitable therapy business because it is secretly a media company and billing company that also delivers therapy services. I can profitably deliver services at far lower costs while still paying my staff higher than average rates because I understand the objective of my business model.

We are required to fill out forms answering questions about how WE think we have been performing.  Then, we are asked about our goals over the next 6 months and 1 year.

After 18 years of showing up to this rodeo, I knew that MY goals didnâ€™t matter - unless they were to attend certain CEU courses, increase my units/visit charged, and to see more patients.

How did I think I did?

Well, I think I got a lot of people better, back to living their lives, and happy that they had me as a therapist.

However, you tell me, Mr. Director.

This review was probably like ones you have been through.  And not unlike most others I had experienced.

There was the discussion that if I added just three more exercises to the patientâ€™s (ther-ex) program at least every other day, how it would positively impact my yearly bonus.

Speaking of adding exercises, this would also help to get my average units/visit up.  This would get me out of â€œlast placeâ€ for the entire company.

My director then requested that I start documenting each week as to why a patient did not attend treatments 3x/wk for that week.  If a patient was discharged, give justification because everyone needed to be seen at a minimum of 15 visits.

As far as documentation went, I needed to get my discharges done sooner.

The response to my goals: â€œWell, I think those are some good goals.â€

Period.

The final outcome:

I wasnâ€™t going to get my full 2% raise because of my shortcomings on the metrics.

You know, the ones that had ZERO to do with patients improving, meeting THEIR goals (which they did).  The goals which they expected us (me) to help them to achieve.

No 2% raise because I focused too much on the patients.

There were many straws during my last 5-6 years with the Establishment.  This was the last one.

However, what was I to do?

I was done with the long hours.

I was done with the endless paperwork.

I was certainly done dealing with the insurance companies.

But, what else was there for me as a therapist?  Being a PT was all I knew.

That was when a patient asked me if I would like to take over for a person who worked with residents in her community.  This individual was moving out of state.  She felt that I was the perfect fit.

Without hesitation I said: â€œHeck YEAH!â€

Scared, nervous, anxious, worried, excited?

Yep.  All of the above.

I didnâ€™t know what I was doing.  No one else was doing this sort of thing.  But I did know one thing: I believed in me.

Where did that decision take me?

I was able to move out of a one bedroom apartment and into a house.  This meant that my kids would now have their own bedrooms.  (BTW, the demands of corporate healthcare were the catalyst to my divorce.)

I was now able to save a little money each month.

I took time off when I wanted.  My clients didnâ€™t mind.  They supported my taking time to myself.

I attended my kidsâ€™ school events.

And I got to focus on what mattered the most about being a therapist - helping people to achieve THEIR goals.

Now, I am blessed to work alongside my friends, Josh and Kevin, to help other clinicians break free from the corporate world, and to become uncaged in their own lives - personally and professionally.

I know that making such a decision is probably the hardest one you will ever make; more so than choosing a partner or spouse.

That is why at UNCAGED we walk with you step-by-step.

We are the safety net beneath you until your wings are strong enough to carry you.

**Original Post:**
Patient fell on ice, with possible rib fracture, male 40yo. No xray.

Going to start with breathwork and education on bracing using pillow.

While we cant fix a broken rib, what other treatments and education can help with pain management and facilitating healing? Should anything be avoided besides mobilizing the effected rib?
TIA!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** i worked with an MVA multiple rib fx and he felt better with taping especially when transfering and with bed mobility; also IDK why but he felt very relaxed and much pain releif with BLE heels on wall on his back (facing the headboard of the bed); he used it after he was sitting up for a while (he was a musician). Once he was able to contract lower abdominals painfree and do basic lumbar stabilization his lower ribs healed faster than the middle ones; we avoided rotation until it was painfree.

> **Response 2:** I would not choose to treat unless there was an X ray performed, especially if this is an initial evaluation and acute.

Deep breathing with an acute rib fracture is going to be very uncomfortable. You can teach avoiding valsalva with movements to decrease the pressure and advise on supporting his arm and avoiding overhead reaching. The advice I would give varies a little depending on which ribs you suspect involvement with.

Iâ€™ve went the hiring route and that has been really hard. 
Iâ€™m willing to scale because I just feel like Iâ€™m burning out and hitting a ceiling.
My front desk girl is helping to market which is great but also there is limited space.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** You didnâ€™t ask a direct question other than tips. And really this is personal. I say this because my wife and I both PTs do mobile as well. I want to see more to make more and can deal with it. She needs more of a break and a healthier balance. 

I say that because you should take a minute or a weekend and write out what you want your life to look like. Your biz and practice should serve as an extension of you to provide you with that life, not take it over. 

From there, a lot of what youâ€™re saying will work itself out. Iâ€™m not saying it will be easy but you should have a closer idea of where you are taking your practice. 

For example, we donâ€™t see ourselves getting a space. We like the flexibility. As much as Iâ€™d love one, it doesnâ€™t serve our life and goals. So we wonâ€™t. And every time I get the desire to get one, we always reference our goals. 

Have your goal, then work backwards. Thereâ€™s lots of options to stay mobile though. You can hire, you can raise prices, set limits on number of Medicare clients, etc.

> **Response 2:** So, my opinion is that the point of being mobile and working for yourself is that you get to control your time. If you feel youâ€™re burning out, cut back. There are a couple ways to do that: hire, stop accepting patients, discharge people, change the type of patients you accept, or raise your prices. You can do any combo of this, but my opinion is that your most lucrative option while also cutting back on hours would be accepting only cash (so commercial insurance based) clients. You can provide superbill a on request, but you have complete control over what you bill, and therefore will be able to see fewer people and still probably get close to what you were making. And most importantly, youâ€™ll burn out less.

### Discussion 218: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-05-19 19:01:00 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 33 reactions, 7 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/970627387041827/

**Original Post:**
Vulnerability. 

I share some of my personal struggles because it's important for people here to see a couple different things. 

1.  It's possible to LOVE life and still have struggles. I love what I get to do, I love who I get to work with, I'm proud of what I've accomplished and live an amazing life. I also struggle with doubts, mindset and mental health issues, and have days that are hard. This is life and even though it seems like people who are successful never have a bad day, thats BS. 
1. It's ok for a leader to show vulnerability. In fact, it's essential. I can't do things on my own. I need others to help me. I need to recognize that despite my best efforts I'll fall short unless surrounded by others to help support me. There's a misconception that building a business on your own is the "courageous" way of doing it. We live in a society where individual work is celebrated and using a team or others to support you is often seen as "cheating" (see school as an example). Trying to do things on your own will get you limited results and the primary reason that people do things on their own is PRIDE. They don't want to show vulnerability because of their pride so they do things on their own and never admit they need help. So by showing my vulnerability I hope to help people see that the smart way, the brave way, the courageous way of doing things is to recognize limitations and ask for help.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** This is exactly what I have found out and am taking action on with myself and my team. Thank you for sharing since this resonates with me so much!

> **Response 2:** This resonates with me so much! Probably one of the biggest lessons I have been learning since starting my practice.

### Discussion 268: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-09-30 18:37:31 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 19 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1565642240873669/

**Original Post:**
Hi y'all! I'm in need of a recommendation! I treat competitive swimmers. A particular female swimmer of mine (high school aged) presented with (bil) shoulder pain in the middle of the summer. She has done 9 PT appts with me (1x/week). Per her words, she no longer has pain but does have a lingering soreness in the anterior shoulders during and after practice. The soreness is not severe enough to have her get out of the water. 

She has horrible shoulder posture and also has a larger chest. Her mother informed me that she has had horrible posture for years (her mother is reportedly always on her case about her posture). I wholeheartedly believe her continued soreness is a result of her posture.

Her mother has asked for a recommendation on a posture bra. I know nothing about posture bras except for what I found during a quick google search. Seems they are built with a mechanism similar to the posture braces that promote scapular retraction. I'm not fond of these braces long-term. I would rather see her continue to strengthen her periscapular muscles and improve her shoulder/scapular stability.

BUT...would a posture bra be a good short-term solution? Can anyone provide any more insight than what you can find googling and/or particular brands recommendations?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Instead of putting a growing adult into some sort of â€œposture braâ€ you should educate her mother that there is very little research that supports â€œperfect postureâ€ and the reason for her pain is because the child is most likely from trying to maintain that posture that her mother expects. Allow the child to sit how they like and let their shoulders relax, I would be surprised if her pain still lingers after that adjustment.

> **Response 2:** As a large chested woman, Iâ€™d focus more on getting her in a correct sized bra. Posture bras do nothing. Instead, she needs to go to a bra fitting store, or Nordstrom. They need to be prepared to spend moneyâ€¦ good bras are not cheap. More than likely, sheâ€™s gone to target or Victorias Secret and is trying to fit herself in to the bras that are available. When she is in a bra that fits, the band should be quite snug. Thatâ€™s where the support comes from. Cup size and band size are inversely related, so if her band has been too big her cup has probably been too small. Once sheâ€™s in the right size bra, then work on posterior chain strengthening to take some of the load off the biceps and pecs.

â€œIf itâ€™s okay, I was hoping to pick your brain a bit? (Before I panic).

I ran my first race since my stress fracture almost 2 weeks ago now (April 23rd- ðŸŽ‰) 9 months post stress fracture. I felt great, no pain, legs were just pretty sore the next day thanks to some tough hills.  

I got sick about mid week after my race, and still am currently sick (I believe theyâ€™ve lovingly called this runners flu)â€¦ I have been laid up since then feeling super run down and havenâ€™t been able to run or really workout- trying to be smart and listen to my body. 

Earlier this week, my ankle started really bothering me- just some deep achy/annoying painâ€¦ and worse at night. Which raised some flags for me. The weather has been yuck so I attributed it to that at first. But the rainy/storms have passed and Iâ€™m still having a constant nagging ache. Worse when Iâ€™m just sitting and still worse at night.

**Original Post:**
Quick question for those who work with those who have become injured playing pickleball? I do work with older clients but am not familiar with the game of pickleball. I'm seeing several groin injuries and am curious what I can do to help these folks reduce the risk of this injury. I believe there is tightness in the adductors and IR of the hips but want to be sure I'm not missing something else.Thank you for any help.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** A big element I work on is footwork. Various foot work drills to help avoid the end ranges of motion during a game. 
â€¦
We canâ€™t change the 40 years of degeneration, but if we can help them move better within the a available range of motion maybe we can reduce the risk of injury.

> **Response 2:** I would say eccentric control of the adductors more than flexibility. There are lots of side to side motions. Think tennis but smaller movements. Lots of changing direction, reflex training, full body twists for swings, etc. Also I read somewhere that pickleball is one of the most "dangerous" sport in that there's the highest injury rate compared to#of players. I'm sure there's a caveat to that stat, maybe the highest rate in racket sports or something. Double check me on that. But there's definitely a huge patient population for us in pickleball!

### Discussion 341: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-07-31 17:02:23 | **Topic:** 11-work-life-mindset-burnout
**Engagement:** 1 reactions, 17 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1803958870375337/

**Original Post:**
Iâ€™m considering switching from OP to HH to have more time to work on my side gig. 

Iâ€™m wondering if there is anyone else that took this route and have any tips or advice on taking this path

Thank you

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Is the side gig in healthcare? How much actual extra time are you needing? I wasnâ€™t attempting to grow a side gig when I tried HH from OP but I fell for the â€œmuch more free timeâ€ or â€œschedule your time offâ€. I just found myself either making up for that time off on another day & as far as free time I found myself working way more from home on documenting then I wanted. & then making calls & scheduling is a whole other headache. Not trying to discourage you just giving my experience on trying HH ðŸ˜…..I lasted two months then went back to OP

> **Response 2:** I was OP, then had a baby and switched to HH 2 decades ago. Last year I went back to OP, but may eventually wander back into HH for the flexibility and money. I wanted a mental challenge by going back to OP (boy, did I get one!) but also was missing camaraderie as HH is very isolating. OP these days is so much more of a grind, and everyone is so stressed. Our clinic has staggered lunches so fun interactions are minimal. HH can be overwhelming (as any new setting would be), but being one on one is such a blessing. Just know that motivation to improve is often much less in HH; many of those folks are fine to be completely sedentary and never perform an HEP, as long as they can make it from the recliner/bed to the toilet/bsc. Good luck! There are definitely advantages to both settings!

### Discussion 373: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-06-01 01:35:41 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 3 reactions, 15 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1481994685905092/

**Original Post:**
Anyone have treated pts with POTS  I have limited experience but want to help this patient and her MD both suffer from this. Or if you can point me to go links or educational places to learn to effectively treat this better.  Thanks very much

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** A PT with POTs here, I've used the Modified CHOP protocol with success for myself, but I wasn't already super deconditioned. 

For my patients, the protocol is often too much too soon for them, but your goals are to stay below manageable levels of symptoms and ideally build strength/cardio in semireclined or reclined positions before standing. 

Also fyi: exercise often can decrease the amount of heart rate increase with activity, and increases a person's capacity, but many will still have symptoms right when they stand, or if they have to stand still (store checkout lines still luck for me)

> **Response 2:** I have treated a patient with EDS & POTS it was a very slow transition over the course of weeks and tolerance varied each visit. We started mostly in hooklying-> slightly elevated-> perched at edge of table progressing to standing next to table with frequent rests, checking BP and she increased tolerance to recumbent bike.
The EDS website has lots of great information on POTS as well.

> **Response 2:** Youâ€™ll have a great time doing this! Iâ€™ve done several and always thoroughly enjoy it. 
From my experience, I would suggest blood pressure checksâ€¦they are quick & open the door for an opportunity to talk more about your services. Sometimes several people are waiting to be checked or to talk, and Iâ€™ve never felt like I had time to do a fall screen.

# *Investment vs. Expense*
## ***6 questions to ask yourself!***

*Starting and growing a business can often feel like a financial strain.*

*How we approach the way in which we look at the purpose of the money being spent from a mindset point can change everything for us.*

*It is pretty well understood what expenses are.*

*In short, an expense is something that costs you money without the opportunity for further growth or time freedom.*

*Investments are when the money spent towards a thing, a service, or even an employee is going to reward us and/or the practice on the backend.*

*In essence, it gives us our time back and/or makes us/the business money.*

*When money is on the table, or being considered, a great question to start with is: Will this (thing putting the money towards) impact our business in a significant way to where we can afford NOT to do it?*

*So often, the first question is can we afford it?  That question can be detrimental because this is attacking it just like you would an expense.*

*There are 5 more questions to ask that will help you to decide if the money potentially being spent is an investment or an expense.*

*Will this give us the ability to serve our customers better? Yes or No?*

*Will it improve my/our ability and knowledge of growing and running the business?*

*Will it help free up more time for me/my employees?*

*Will it make a difference in how satisfied our customers are?*

*Will it help to differentiate me/my practice in the market, and make me/the practice more different than I/it already am/is?*

*Answering â€œYesâ€ to any of these questions is a good indicator that the money is going to help make the business better for (us) and for (our) customers.*

*When we immediately write off things (say â€œNoâ€) because it doesnâ€™t fit in the budget, then we are approaching them with an expense mindset.*

*Send me a DM if you are ready to invest in yourself!*

### Discussion 438: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT]

**Original Post:**
Looking for some guidance. I have a client who complains of "dizziness" only with bending forward to pick items up off the floor. She reports double vision with looking all the way left or all the way right, like in the peripheral vision. She has Graves with some eye protrusion and a history of a MVA 20 years ago but was dealing with multiple fractures and surgeries so she isn't sure if she had a concussion or other head trauma but doesn't recall being told about any head trauma. I was not able to elicit nystagmus with roll test or dix hall-pike. Eye gaze appeared WNL. Neck ROM WNL. I gave some habituation exercises but feel like I am missing something. Any advice would be appreciated. Thank you

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** In terms of eyes: Graves Disease can lead to double vision due to scar tissue shortening an ocular muscle. Check and see if with monocular (one eye only) viewing that the double vision is improved. Would recommend ophthalmologist vs. neuro-ophthalmologist.

Did you perform ligamentous testing, or vertebral artery screen? How are smooth pursuits/saccades? Can look at smooth pursuit neck torsion test to rule in cervicogenic component. If there is laxity in ligamentous testing, may want to see about flexion/extension XRay for cervical instability. Cervical impairments/instability can of course lead to double vision, but also degradation in smooth pursuit especially. 

Also assessing in general her balance, sensory integration (CTSIB), to see how that fits in the picture.   Happy to help however I can ðŸ˜Š

> **Response 2:** Not sure about the double vision part.. But with multiple facial fractures, I am thinking possibly sinusitis. Only thing that made me think that was I recently had sinusitis and bending over made me feel extremely dizzy that I almost fell over. Another symptom was that I would tap/gently hit my head and literally felt like I was getting concussed bc i was so dizzy from each hit (I was light sparring, that's why my head was getting hit lol). I also had a headache. I did sinus massage and it's insane bc I could feel it draining from my sinuses. I YouTubed a bunch of stuff and then I had a friend do a sinus massage too. Anyways, just a thought!

(Edited to add that I realized you just said fractures, not specifically facial fractures. Oops!)

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Come on you guys. Baker cyst is a reservoir where the swelling accumulates because there's nowhere for it to go. It is likely from a torn meniscus or damage to the cartilage. Apply as a non participating provider. Just you. Not your company.

Get a contract. Accept the terms. Sign your contract. 

Wait a little while and call back and say "I've hired more therapists and I need to have my company listed as a group provider, yes I'm already in your network." Credential your other providers, get new contact, viola! Merry Christmas 2023... You're fully in network.

### Discussion 492: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-12-15 15:28:23 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice

**Original Post:**
For those of you who practice in a gym setting and take Medicare - any guidance on answering the application question â€œis this private office space used exclusively for the applicantâ€™s private practice?â€ 

Initially I answered no, and got my application back stating I had made a â€œtypographical errorâ€ on that question. This was among other items that needed to be changed. Having a hard time getting a hold of the Novitas rep to ask the question. 

Details about my setup:

The treatment room Iâ€™m using is at the back of a local gym (you enter through the gym) and is also used as a dance or yoga studio, spin class at other times of day, but not when Iâ€™m there for business. No patient information stored there. 

Iâ€™m assuming that theyâ€™d flag it on the site visit if it doesnâ€™t meet Medicare standards based on my application, and I wouldnâ€™t find out much later that Iâ€™m in violation of any rulesâ€¦ but this is a fledgling practice and Iâ€™m quite risk averse in this arena.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** CMS Guidance on "exclusive use of space" is provided in the Code of Federal Regulations, and is cited in IOM 100-02, Ch. 15, Â§230.4.  

Space is referenced in CMS 855i (and PECOS) Section 2 (K).  "If you responded YES to questions 2, 3 or 4 above, you must have and attach a copy of any written agreement that gives you exclusive use of the office space for PT/OT services."

"Office" is therapy space... (don't confuse w/home or admin "office".  Office = Clinic in therapy parlance.

A therapy supplier is required to upload copy of the lease (contract) showing exclusive use of space... Given a supplier may only be using space on selected dates/times... lease must reflect the times/space that is exclusive use.

CMS has guidance in other therapy guidance for space (time/section); the OIG has provided official guidance on calculating space/time for purpose of amount $$.  (many steps prior to getting to FMV). 

#Risk needs to be mitigated on the application by understanding GoToTheSource rules...  

Glad to provide a quick tip to anyone needing it... not a solicitation for business

> **Response 2:** Nancy Beckley's Compliance Rules Will be correcting my answer posted below earlier.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I have POTS and work with many patients with POTS.  I donâ€™t have a protocol per seâ€¦ but you basically just have to meet your patient where they are and have compassion. The thing about POTS is its autonomic dysfunction.  The nervous system will literally do what it wants, when wants, with no explanation or reasoning. So when your patients sound crazy that they canâ€™t do a single bridge one day, when they did 30 squats the day beforeâ€¦. They arenâ€™t faking it. 
With exercise you have to realize they have really low blood pressure post of the time. So when they are at their worst, you start with seriously WHATEVER they can do. Supine glute squeezes.  Iâ€™ve had patients I had to start with 5 glute squeezesâ€¦ and thatâ€™s all they can do.  You start with supine exercises so the blood doesnâ€™t rush out of their head being upright. But you want to increase time of their muscles to out pressure on the blood vessels. Go slow, and let them tell you what they can and canâ€™t do. And literallyâ€¦ if some days they canâ€™t do anythingâ€¦ then they canâ€™t do anything. Increase salt intake like crazy. I use LMNT packets. No sugar, high sodium. I literally could have 4 of those a day or more sometimes. Itâ€™s really about the patient leading their own NEW body and their boundaries and you listening.  The problem with most of these patients is that EVERYONE in the medical community has told them they are crazy. So as long as you listen and are compassionateâ€¦ you will help them in a way no one else has

### Discussion 656: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-11-01 10:53:50 | **Topic:** 11-work-life-mindset-burnout
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 10 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1590159075088652/

**Original Post:**
Occupational therapist here with 13 years of experience soon to interview for a 3 x 10-hour weekend acute care position.

 (1) In relation to a traditional 40-hour work week, what would you expect the salary to be for this position? Do you feel it should be 75% of a 40-hour work week salary or incentivized with a bit higher salary for the non-traditional schedule? 

(2) What would your concerns be for this schedule? Topics to address during the interview?

Thanks for your time!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I thought they made pretty close to a full salary. When I worked in home care we had therapists who worked Friday Saturday Sunday or Saturday Sunday Monday and they made a full, full-time salary.

> **Response 2:** As a weekend therapist I would ask what the incentive for weekend work is and I would ask how many weekends you are allowed to ask off for. Even as a full time weekday therapist in both acute and home health there is a weekend differential, so I got paid a little bit more for my weekend hours than my weekday hours, so as someone who dedicates all weekends I would expect that as well. 
Benefit would be similar to a nursing schedule, when you take one weekend off you have nearly two weeks of days off with only taking 30 hours PTO. but, like i said, ask how many weekends youâ€™re allowed to ask off for. I worked for a hospital and we had a weekend warrior team, and I think they were allowed 4 weekends for PTO requests. Obviously if something came up we made it work, like family emergency, bereavement, etc. but as requests off they were limited in how many they could ask for in the year. But they got paid a fairly hefty differential, more than just the weekend differential for weekday clinicians. 
Also ask if there is a time commitment, our weekend warriors signed on for a year commitment to the weekend plan. Again, they got paid a nice differential to do it so it was mostly our younger/new grads who would do it for 1-2 years for the extra pay, and then transition to weekday team

### Discussion 768: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-10-11 07:51:48 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 9 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1333974174040478/

**Original Post:**
Has anyone started a Med B outpatient business and then added on a Med A home health practice?

I have a mobile part B practice and I see many TKR and THR patients.  I started thinking, what if I could also do their home health part and then transition into their outpatient part?

Can this be done?  Does it work? Would I need to have 2 separate companies?

(This is what happens when you are awake at 1am!!)

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Donâ€™t become a HH agency, rather become an IC and partner with several HH agencies and use their EMR or one that is compatible. So youâ€™d become a â€œstaffing/contractâ€ company for those HH visits then provide your med B practice info as a referral option.

> **Response 2:** Technically you can do it. However, part A home health is highly highly regulated with crazy strict rules. Documentation and billing are very complicated. You would need help. You would need a HH specific oasis EMR, you would likely need a consultant that can help you understand all the rules and regs, if you are not familiar with oasis, I recommend taking a course on the oasis and you would need to hire an oasis scrubber and biller familiar with home health. You would also need an RN. You can't do home health as therapy only. You'd need an admin RN as well as a field RN. Feel free to message me if you have more questions. I was a HH director for years before burning out and becoming uncaged, I know a lot about HH Med A.

Does anyone have a quick formula for converting a desired number of patient visits per week to the necessary evals per week to maintain that caseload. Iâ€™m trying to work backwards from a goal of about 20 visits a week, knowing I probably see most patients for an average length of treatment of about 8 visits. How many evals a week am I aiming for to maintain 20 visits a week. I know thereâ€™s a formula out there for this somewhere. Thanks in advance!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** 80 visits per month Ã· 8 visits average length of stay.  (Assuming 2 visits per week per patient) 
Each month u need to replace 80Ã·8 or 10% of your caseload.  So if u see each patient ~2x/week than u need 8 evals per month (or 2 per week)  if u see each 1x per week than u need 1 per week. (This would be the math if u are already at 20 visits/week)

**Original Post:**
Hi all! Trying to decide if I should wait it out or make an appointment for my knee. As of about a week ago my knee started feeling kind of weak like it will just give out but not enough to concern me. Then on Monday I had some pain while working out but the movements that bothered it wasnâ€™t consistent: sometimes flexion would hurt, then other times extension would but pain would be in different areas. Today it felt fine all day and during my workout this morning but now tonight itâ€™s swollen, hurts and feels like it could give out when I stand on 1 leg. Occasionally some achy pain that goes down my calf. Just looking for suggestions, recommendations and if I should go in!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Do you have a connection with a solid PT who can take a look at you?

> **Response 2:** Hey Michelle! I like to go through potentials whenever I, a family member or a patient is wondering why something is going wrong. 

Let's run through some potentials. Based on sudden onset and no mechanism of injury, we are really left with OA or maybe a bursitis (not super likely though, right?) 

It also does not seem to be following a certain movement pattern (let's start thinking systemic). Gout, septic arthritis, and DVTs are all potentials that could explain your symptoms.

**Original Post:**
Hey yâ€™all! So one of my goals for the rest of this year is to create more content to develop into a blog for my websiteâ€¦ Which is relatively nonexistent right nowðŸ˜œ 

I am not a good writer so Iâ€™m going to be just talking into my notes app for various topics that strike me as Iâ€™m driving to further develop. Hoping to find someone to do some editing to help me out with that end of it. Do any of yâ€™all Do anything similar or know of any other easy platforms to use or what not?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Hire a VA. Let them write it for you. Buy private label rights. You are welcome. ðŸ˜ðŸ˜ðŸ˜

> **Response 2:** Keep in mind, these blog posts are not creative writing. Depending on the purpose of your blog it should take little to no actual thought.
...
My blog is to gain traffic. Traffic generates ad revenue, increases the value and authority of my website, and will eventually build an email list that will sell digital content.
...
My blog is not intended to convert visitors into paid clients in my clinic.
...
So knowing the purpose of my blog posts the most important thing is to simply answer questions. 
...
You don't need to be a good writer... I mean you don't need to write well in order to answer a question like "Is it normal for my feet to swell after a total knee replacement?"
...
Everything here is very technical. Use a framework.
...
Choose a keyword based on search traffic numbers. > Identify the top 3 to 5 related keywords. Choose your main keyword and put that in the title, H2, first sentence and last sentence. Then make the next 3 or 4 H2's the related keywords in question format. Then answer those questions in 200 to 250 words each.
...
Take original photos, optimize the photo file name, alt tag, and title with your keyword.
...
Embed video - either your own or someone else's from YouTube.
...
You have done this a thousand times already in your documentation and talking to patients. Turn off your brain and just follow the steps. 
...
Paint by number.

### Discussion 1192: 

**Date:** 2025-05-21 17:16:33 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 3 reactions, 4 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1746247342813157/

**Original Post:**
Has anyone used shockwave device for ED and would have a protocol to share? I am getting a device to try for 45 days but the company says they canâ€™t give a protocol for it since it is off label use.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Thanks for bringing up this important topic. When considering shockwave therapy for ED, itâ€™s essential to understand the difference between focused and radial shockwave technologies. I don't know what device you are getting for the trial period?

Focused shockwave therapy delivers energy deeper into tissue with high precision. It operates with a rise time of less than 10 nanoseconds, which is a key factor in triggering biological effects like neovascularization, as supported by research in the treatment of erectile dysfunction.

Radial shockwave devices, including those like SoftWave, stemware, Omniwave, Hwave, etc., have slower rise times and lower peak pressures. These systems disperse energy more broadly and do not penetrate deeply enough to reach the cavernosal tissue involved in ED as effectively as focused devices.

That said, I want to be clear that I am not criticizing any particular device. This is purely my experience and personal opinion based on years of using both focused and radial technologies. Please make informed decisions, especially when considering off-label applications like ED treatment.

Itâ€™s also important to note that ED treatment may fall outside the physical therapy scope of practice in many states. Always check the FDA 510(k) clearance, technical specifications like peak pressure and rise time, and be cautious of marketing claims.

Hereâ€™s a helpful article comparing focused and radial shockwave for ED:
https://consultqd.clevelandclinic.org/trial-compares-shockwave-versus-radial-wave-therapy-for-erectile-dysfunction-in-prostate-cancer-survivors.  Also, find the ESWT Guidelines here ( Page 103 for ED )   :https://shockwavetherapy.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/ISMST-Guidelines-for-ESWT-_-engl-20240103.pdf

Needing help or advice on getting medical benefits for employees. I'm a small pediatric private practice in Austin Texas.

I currently need some form of medical benefits for one employee now and for another one starting in January. Does anyone have any thoughts and suggestions on plans or providing a stipend for a healthï¿¼share?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I would start with offering supplemental benefits, like accident/injury, hospitalization, short-term disability, major life event. The two big companies that handle this are AFLAC and Unum. I am personally an agent for AFLAC because AFLAC is the only company that covers mental health hospitalization as a hospitalization as well as as For a short term disability due to mental health reasons etc. also, AFLAC is the only supplemental health plan that pays out for hospitalization. As long as you are in the hospital for 18 hours. Every other plan is 24 hours. This may seem like not a big deal but I was actually once hospitalized for 23 hours and I went to submit my claim to Unum and it didnâ€™t qualify but it would have if I had AFLAC. And thatâ€™s $1000 difference.  Otherwise every state is different as far as insurance is concerned for health sharing plans. Otherwise look into QSEHRA (Qualified Small Employer Health Reimbursement Arrangement)

> **Response 2:** I have a local friend who does the is for companies. I can message you his info if you want.

Clinical question - 92 y/o patient fell and developed hematoma in the brachialis region of right forearm. Doesnâ€™t have full supination PROM or AROM and painful. She fell a week ago. 

When/do I suggest imaging to role out fracture? Sheâ€™s had imaging and they didnâ€™t see anything. She has full AROM elbow flexion and extension. 

TIA

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** X Ray can miss up to 30% of nondosplacrd radial head fractures. You may also have concerns for bicep rupture (do hook test) or supinator tear. Diagnostic ultrasound would be the quickest way to identify muscle pathology.

> **Response 2:** If sheâ€™s had imaging it is likely fine. Iâ€™d wait until roughly 2 week post fall at this point to see if ROM improves. 

If passive pronation/supination improves with the elbow flexed to 90, itâ€™s likely soft tissue. If elbow position has no effect then that adds to the concern.

Pain with axial loading? Also if she has likelihood of gaining functional range, the conversation of â€˜is surgery worth itâ€™ comes into play. Because quality of life may be preserved more effectively without.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Iâ€™m married to a registered dietitian and work with him for our side coaching business. I hear a lot of other PTs try to give nutrition advice, and it often times ends up being a disservice to the patients / clients. The best thing you can do for your clients if refer them to an RD. **Original Post:**
Question for my Pediatric experts out there.
What is the efficacy or are outcomes good with pre-operative PT tongue/lip tie in infants? Or is the frenectomy the usual outcome anyway? Friend of mine was asking about his new child.

I also recommend ST and OT as well but just looking for info for him.  Thanks in advance! Didn't get a great response in other groups I posted so figured I'd cross post here.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Definitely want to work with a good IBCLC plus a therapist who is trained in infant oral motor skills and Myofascial release pre and post frenectomy. > **Response 2:** PT is great for pre and post release when done with a therapist who has taken the appropriate coursework, but therapy wonâ€™t take away the need for a frenectomy if the child needs it. PT can help with decreasing tension, improving ROM, and helping with motor skills for little ones with TOTs ðŸ˜Š.

### Discussion 1593: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-09-12 16:45:04 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 5 reactions, 1 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1316056662498896/

**Original Post:**
5 ways to calm the brain when stress is getting to us.

Have you ever had days - or periods of time - where you had so much extraneous stuff going on that your brain felt like a jar of marbles that had spilled, and marbles were bouncing everywhere?

We are  sure you know the feeling.  We all have experienced this.  Some of us more than others.

Things such as disappointments with business/work, the kids are sick, struggles with the spouse or significant other, and a host of other topics can certainly create massive distractions.

Chaos in the head can make it a challenge to focus on the necessary task at hand.

When left unchecked, this can put us in a funk for days making it difficult to regain our focus for being productive.

When/if you find yourself in this predicament, here are five techniques that we suggest for bringing order to the bouncing marble balls.

They do not have to be carried out in this order, but we do suggest that you engage in all five for full effectiveness.

1:Pick one thing to act on.  The success from tackling one thing will help to build back your momentum for getting other boxes checked.

2:Reflect on what has been working for you, or the things that you do well.

3:You can turn the wreckage around through praise.  Praise can be done through listening to uplifting music, or by reading books that contain a positive message. Choose whatever is encouraging for you.  It may be songs that get you pumped up, songs that soothe you, or media that has spiritual content.

4:Journaling is a phenomenal tool for bringing calm to a maelstrom.

Not everyone is a writer.  But there are times when sitting down with pen and paper in a peaceful place can do wonders.

5:Whenever you find yourself in distress or in unrest, we encourage you to Pray.  Regardless of your beliefs, pray.  Speak to the universe, to nature,  or to whomever is dominant in your Faith.  This does wonders for clearing the mind. Putting your thoughts out there will very often lead to you  answering  your own questions, or solving your own dilemmas.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Weâ€™ve run into this too and itâ€™s super frustrating. 

A couple of things usually make a difference. First, the CRM youâ€™re using can play a big role since some are much better at filtering spam than others. Hosting matters tooâ€”certain platforms are just more vulnerable. And of course, captcha is a big one. If you donâ€™t have reCAPTCHA or hCaptcha turned on, thatâ€™s worth trying because it usually cuts down the noise in a big way.

Sometimes itâ€™s also about looking under the hood. If the submissions are all coming from the same IP range, you can block them right at the host level. And if they still sneak through, you can add filtering rules inside your CRM so the junk never even hits your inbox.

Curiousâ€”what platform are you on right now, and do you have captcha enabled? Thatâ€™ll help point to the best fix.

Any foot/ankle specialists out there?

I have a patient with metatarsalgia. However, upon examination he had a neuroma removed between his 3rd and 4th digit one year ago, and he has significant scar tissue there which feels like is pushing his 4th metatarsal head inferiorly and his bone is protruding inferiorly.  Scar tissue mobs, strengthening and shockwave is helping. 

However, the patient naturally doesnâ€™t heel strike.  He doesnâ€™t even land mid strike.  He lands on his metatarsal heads.  With education he is working in thisâ€¦ but Iâ€™m wondering if a zero drop shoe would help facilitate a heel strike better? 

Any thoughts are appreciated!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Agree that low drop shoe might not be the first choice if youâ€™re looking to promote easy heel strike. If itâ€™s irritable it might be worth considering a slightly more cushioned shoe that isnâ€™t zero drop. But I think considering a wide toe box would still be beneficial!

Also, possibly not relevant but Iâ€™ve noticed it on myself, may be worth looking up the chain and seeing if he is carrying his weight in his forefeet because of proximal posture.

> **Response 2:** Hey there, what type of shoe is he currently in? Is this with running or walking? Same pattern both feet? I think youâ€™re right on with considering his strike pattern as an aggravating factor. Obviously there can be exceptions, but generally a lower drop/zero drop shoe tends to encourage less rearfoot strike, not more. Iâ€™d also be curious to see how this patient would do in a more rockered shoe (not necessarily long term, but in the short term) - sometimes this can take stress off the metatarsals since itâ€™s generally going to reduce the bending forces here and the amount of loaded MTP extension needed. Hello all,
question about receipts (again!)
I had pt give me gratitude tip for massage service. When giving them receipt should I list only my normal rate for massage? Add some kind of subcategory for drive fee, and tip or not include them at all?
They would like to submit receipt to insurance for reimbursement.

> **Response 1:** If they are paying the full amount with debit/credit card (or even now the applepay/phone tap payments) there is an E-paper trail that will be reported anyway, so giving a full accounting on your own receipt is the smart choice. You protect your own tax scenario before trying to advantage the clientâ€™s situation.

### Discussion 2000: 

**Date:** 2024-07-13 12:56:25 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 1 reactions, 1 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1509968026441091/

**Original Post:**
So question for anyone who has just opened an outpatient practice. How many patients would you consider too many when doors open. I am in the unusual spot of having a chiro practice close and patients seeing my sign out front opening soon. Now have 25 patients interested. Which I guess is good but still setting up and need to reverify and then enter all the info into EMR which still learning. Just curious if anyone else has been in this situation and how they handled it.  Dont want to be like all other facilities in area which are corporate. Oh and we are OON and medicare but some of chiro was MVA patients.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** You are in charge of scheduling. 

Could set a weekly visit cap for yourself (e.g., no more than x visits total for a given week) to get your feet under you. It would create a waiting list which is fine, and most anyone should understand that you are a one person show just getting started. 

Could have a special event to do brief consults with everyone interested to see if they're a good fit and would benefit most from your services vs someone else's.

Could post your prices and let some of them self select themselves out of the process (always view this as a "no for now").

Exciting problem to have!! Congrats on the early interest.

Dear Uncaged Community - Are you a Neuro PT in the U.S.? If yes, I am a neurologic physical therapist and researcher hoping many of you would consider completing my IRB approved annonymous qualtrics survey:

[https://samuelmerritt.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_djtgBvo56bSr0Bo](https://samuelmerritt.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_djtgBvo56bSr0Bo) 

This research is approved by the Pacific University human subjects ethics committee and invites all physical therapists (PT) who identify as neurologic PTs with or without obtaining a neurologic clinical specialty by the American Board of Physical Therapy Specialties who practice in the United States to participate in this data gathering process by completing a 10-15 min survey. 

We want to better understand the leadership practices of Neurologic Physical Therapists, as well as explore the subgroup of neuro PTs developing Neurologic Health Promotion and Wellness practices to define and describe this emerging landscape. Neurologic Physical Therapists bridging the gap between rehabilitation and wellness for people with neurologic disability are under researched and little is known about these innovative practices and the leaders supporting them. Thank you for your consideration! Please message me with any questions.
